sen.j: 雑役（ぞうやく/ざつえき）とは、平安時代中期以後に導入された租税体系のこと。
sen.e: Zoyaku/Zoeki is the term for the taxation system introduced after the middle of the Heian period.

sen.j: 律令制の租税である租が変質したと考えられる官物・年貢に対して、雑徭など人身別賦課を引く雑公事・夫役・臨時雑役などを指して称した（庸・調の後身に関しては官物説と雑役説の両方がある）。
sen.e: Whereas Kanbutsu and Nengu are considered as the transformation of the tax, So, of the Ritsuryo system(a system of centralized government based on the ritsuryo code), Zoyaku/Zoeki indicated Zokoji, Fueki, Rinji Zoyaku that are considered as a continuance of per-capita tax, Zoyo (There are both Kanbutu tax and Zoeki tax regarded to be descended from Yo and Cho).

Whereas Kanbutsu and Nengu are considered as the transformation of the tax, So, of the Ritsuryo system (a system of centralized government based on the ritsuryo code), Zoyaku/Zoeki indicated Zokoji, Fueki, Rinji Zoyaku that are considered as a continuance of a per-capita tax, Zoyo (There are both Kanbutu tax and Zoeki tax regarded to be descended from Yo and Cho).

Whereas Kanmotsu (tribute goods paid as taxes or tithes) and Nengu (land tax) are considered as the transformation of the tax, So (rice tax) of the Ritsuryo system (a system of centralized government based on the ritsuryo code), Zoyaku indicated Zokuji (all miscellaneous dues in the form of non-rice products and labor), Buyaku (labor service), Rinji Zoyaku (extraordinary irregular levies) that are considered as a continuance of a per-capita tax, Zoyo (irregular corvee) (regarding what the taxes of Yo [labor or alternative goods] and Cho [textile goods or alternative money] transformed into, there are two theories: one theory asserts Kanmotsu and another Zoyaku).
sen.cmt: zoyaku のみとしました。Zokuji と読みを変更しました。雑公事、夫役、臨時雑役 補足を追加しました。

sen.j: なお、予め国司などに申請して雑役を免除を受ける公田・荘園もあった。
sen.e: There were koden and shoen that applied to the Kokushi in advance to be exempt from Soeki.

There were koden (field administered directly by a ruler) and shoen (manor in medieval Japan) that applied to the Kokushi in advance to be exempt from Zoyaku.
sen.cmt: 公田、荘園 補足を追加しました。

sen.e: This was called Zoyakumen (exemption of Zoyaku).

sen.j: 当初は有力な公民に対する賦課として行われる形式を採っていたが、11世紀中期の官物率法の成立を機に次第に土地に対する賦課へと変質していった。
sen.e: Originally it was a tax on prominent citizens, but with the establishment of Kanbuturippo in the middle of the eleventh century, it transformed into a tax against land.
